title: What AI Can’t Do — a white space workbook
author: Christie Parrow

paragraphs: This is not a productivity workbook.
There are no goals to set, no habits to track, no 30-day challenge waiting at the end. You will not find a single affirmation in here.

What you will find are six questions about the skills you already have — the ones that don’t show up on a resume, the ones AI can’t learn from a dataset, the ones you stopped calling skills because no one ever gave you credit for them.

You know how to read a room. You know when to speak and when to let someone else figure it out. You know how to make people feel safe enough to say the honest thing. These are not soft skills. These are the only skills that still belong entirely to you.
This workbook won’t teach you anything. You already know all of it. It just asks you to write it down — in your own hand, in your own words — so you can stop forgetting what you bring.
Use a pen. Take your time. There’s no grade.

data.prompt: Name a skill you use every single day that has never appeared on your resume.
data.example: I make tense rooms lighter. Not in a “let me tell a joke” way — more like I can feel when everyone’s holding their breath, and I say the slightly funny, slightly honest thing that lets people exhale. I’ve done this in every job I’ve ever had. HR has never once asked about it in an interview.

data.quote: “I write entirely to find out what I’m thinking.” — Joan Didion

data.prompt: What do people come to you for that has nothing to do with your job title?
data.example: People come to me when they need to say something out loud before they’re ready to say it to the person it’s actually about. I’m the rehearsal. I’m the “does this sound crazy?” phone call. I don’t charge for this. I probably should.

data.quote: “I am deliberate and afraid of nothing.” — Audre Lorde

data.prompt: What is something you are deeply good at that you have stopped calling a skill?
data.example: Knowing when to lead and when to shut up. I can feel the exact moment a meeting needs someone to take over, and I can also feel when the best move is to let someone else figure it out while I just nod and hold the space. This isn’t “leadership” the way a business book describes it. It’s more like rhythm. I always know whose turn it is.

data.quote: “The thing you are most afraid to write. Write that.” — Nayyirah Waheed

data.prompt: What would you spend your time doing if no algorithm, job board, or LinkedIn post could ever see it?
data.example: I would write. Not content — just writing. Letters to people I love, the kind where you actually say the thing instead of liking their post. I’d sit somewhere warm with a pen and no strategy and make something that doesn’t need a caption.

data.quote: “There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.” — Maya Angelou

data.prompt: Name one thing AI will never be able to do that you did this week.
data.example: I made my friend laugh while she was crying. Not to fix it — I just said something so specific and stupid that she couldn’t help it. Then she cried more. Then she laughed again. That’s a skill. Try prompting ChatGPT to do that.

data.quote: “The only way out is through.” — Robert Frost

data.prompt: Write one sentence that starts with “I bring” — and do not follow it with a job title.
data.example: I bring the joke right before the hard conversation that makes everyone realize we’re going to be fine.

data.quote: “If you do not breathe through writing, if you do not cry out in writing, then don’t write.” — Anaïs Nin

headline: If six questions changed something,
the full workbook has fifty.
data.bridge: you already know how to do this.
